title: How to Export an iMovie Video in HD

steps.title: Open iMovie.
steps.content: Open iMovie. Use this method if you want to export an HD video to a folder on your Mac. Once the video is exported, you can view and share it as you wish.

steps.title: Click the movie you want to export in the “Libraries” pane.
steps.content: Click the movie you want to export in the “Libraries” pane.

steps.title: Click the File menu at the top of the screen.
steps.content: Click the File menu at the top of the screen.

steps.title: Click Share.
steps.content: Click Share . [1] X Research source

steps.title: Select File… in the Share menu.
steps.content: Select File… in the Share menu. If you want to share your video directly to a website, click the name of that website (Facebook, YouTube, Vimeo, etc) instead. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Type a name for your movie in the text box.
steps.content: Type a name for your movie in the text box. If you're sharing the video to a website, this text will become the title of the movie.

steps.title: Type some tags into the “Tags” box.
steps.content: Type some tags into the “Tags” box. This is helpful if you're sharing to YouTube or Vimeo and want to make it easy for others to find your video.

steps.title: Click the “Resolution” menu to pick a resolution.
steps.content: Click the “Resolution” menu to pick a resolution. Choose 720p, 1080p, or 4k for HD. Not all options will be available for all movies as you can't turn low quality video into HD. 720p is HD at 1280 x 720 resolution. Choose this for a high quality file that uploads quickly and doesn't take up much hard drive space. 1080p is HD at 1920 x 1080 resolution—5 times the quality of 720p. You'll have a bigger file and longer upload than with 720p. 4k is Ultra High Definition (UHD), which is 4096 x 2160 resolution. This is 4 times the quality of 1080p, so expect a large file with a lengthy upload time.

steps.title: Set other parameters if you're sharing your video to a website.
steps.content: Set other parameters if you're sharing your video to a website. If you're exporting to a file, you can skip this step. Click the “Categories” menu to choose a YouTube category. Click the “Viewable to” or “Privacy” menu to set the privacy.

steps.title: Click the “Quality” menu to set your video quality.
steps.content: Click the “Quality” menu to set your video quality. You won't see this if you're sharing to a website. To get an idea of how each setting affects the file size, click an option to see the file size beneath the preview. [3] X Research source Choosing “High” will give you the best results without making the file too large. Choosing “Best” will use ProRes, which is professional quality. The size will be very large.

steps.title: Click the “Compress” menu to choose your compression rate.
steps.content: Click the “Compress” menu to choose your compression rate. This option is only visible if you're exporting to a file. Choose “Faster” if you're worried about file size. The quality won't be as good, but it should still be better than SD (standard). Choose “Better Quality” if you prefer the clearest possible audio and video and don't care about file size, this is the option for you.

steps.title: Click Next.
steps.content: Click Next . If you're sharing to a website, you'll be prompted to enter your account information for that site. Follow the prompts to sign in and complete the upload. When the upload is complete, you'll see “Share Successful.”

steps.title: Type a name for the video into the “Save As” field.
steps.content: Type a name for the video into the “Save As” field.

steps.title: Navigate to the folder where you want to save the file.
steps.content: Navigate to the folder where you want to save the file. Save the file to a folder you'll remember, like Documents or Desktop, so it's easy to access when you want to upload it to YouTube , burn it to DVD, etc.

steps.title: Click Save.
steps.content: Click Save . After a few moments, you'll be able to find the HD version of your movie in the folder you chose. [4] X Research source Now that the video is saved as an HD file on your computer, you can upload it to sites like Facebook, LinkedIn, Google Drive, Dropbox, and any other site that accepts high-quality video.

steps.title: Open the iMovie app on your iPhone or iPad.
steps.content: Open the iMovie app on your iPhone or iPad. If you're currently editing a project, tap Done at the top left corner. and then skip to step 4. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Videos at the top of the screen.
steps.content: Tap Videos at the top of the screen. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Tap the video you want to share.
steps.content: Tap the video you want to share.

steps.title: Tap the Share icon.
steps.content: Tap the Share icon. It's at the bottom of the screen and looks like a square with an upward-pointing arrow.

steps.title: Tap a sharing method.
steps.content: Tap a sharing method. You can choose an app with which to share your video, or a location where you'd it to be saved. For example, tap the Facebook icon if you want to share the video on Facebook. If you want to save the video as a file to your iPhone or iPad (you can always share it later), choose “Save Video.”

steps.title: Follow the prompts to sign in.
steps.content: Follow the prompts to sign in. If sharing on an app like Facebook or YouTube, enter your sign-in information as stated in the on-screen instructions.

steps.title: Select your desired HD resolution.
steps.content: Select your desired HD resolution. Choose from 4k (Ultra HD), 1080p (HD), or 720p (HD). Note that not all apps or services support larger HD files, so you may not see all of these options. [7] X Research source 720p is 1280 x 720 resolution. The file size will stay small despite the video being HD-quality. 1080p is HD at 1920 x 1080 resolution—5 times the quality of 720p. The save or upload will take longer than 720p. 4k is 4096 x 2160 resolution, which is 4 times the quality of 1080p. Expect a large file with a lengthy upload time.

steps.title: Follow the prompts to export the video.
steps.content: Follow the prompts to export the video. If using YouTube or Facebook, you may have to use the app or website to set up tags and descriptions.
